translated: Treatise on the Five Categories of the SarvÄstivÄda School
Åšramaá¹‡a Dharma-siddhi, Tripiá¹­aka Master and Great Virtuous One of the Great Fan Kingdom
In the Dharma-hall of Xidu Temple in Gansu
There are five kinds of dharmas:
First, form dharmas;
Second, mind dharmas;
Third, mental factors;
Fourth, dharmas not associated with the mind;
Fifth, unconditioned dharmas.
What are called form dharmas?
They are all forms produced from the four great elements and the four derivative forms.
What are the four great elements?
The earth element, water element, fire element, and wind element.
What are called derivative forms?
They are the eye faculty, ear faculty, nose faculty, tongue faculty, and body faculty, as well as forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and part of tangibles, along with unmanifest form.
What are called mind dharmas?
They are mind, thought, and consciousness.
What are they further? They are the six groups of consciousness: eye consciousness, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.
What are called mental factors?
It refers to all dharmas that are associated with the mind.
What are they?

It refers to feeling, perception, volition, contact, attention, desire, resolve, faith, vigor, mindfulness, concentration, wisdom, investigation, analysis, heedlessness, heedfulness, wholesome roots, unwholesome roots, indeterminate roots, all bonds, fetters, minor afflictions, entanglements, abiding, knowledge, views, all realizations, and other such dharmas that are associated with the mind. These are called mental factors.
What are called dharmas not associated with the mind?
It refers to those dharmas that are not associated with the mind.
What are they?

Namely, acquisition, formless concentration, cessation concentration, formless attainments, life faculty, homogeneity, acquisition of place, acquisition of things, acquisition of place, birth, aging, abiding, impermanence, name-group, sentence-group, and syllable-group. There are also other dharmas not associated with mind. Such categories are called dharmas not associated with mind.
What are called unconditioned dharmas?
There are three kinds of unconditioned:
Space, non-analytical cessation, and analytical cessation. These are called unconditioned dharmas.
What is the earth element?
It is the quality of solidity.
What is the water element?
It is the quality of fluidity.
What is the fire element?
It is the quality of heat.
What is the wind element?
It is the quality of lightness and movement.
What is the eye faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for visual consciousness.
What is the ear faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis for auditory consciousness.
What is the nose faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis of the nose consciousness.
What is the tongue faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis of the tongue consciousness.
What is the body faculty?
It refers to the pure form that is the basis of the body consciousness.
What are the various forms?

It refers to the various good forms, bad forms, and the forms that abide in between those two, as well as the various colors and so forth. The first form is cognized by the eye consciousness, experienced by the eye consciousness, and known by the mental consciousness.
Therefore, the various forms are cognized by the eye consciousness and the mental consciousness, by these two consciousnesses.
What are the various sounds?
Sounds are of two kinds: those produced by the great elements that are appropriated, and those produced by the great elements that are not appropriated.
The first sound is cognized by the ear consciousness, experienced by the ear consciousness, and known by the mental consciousness.
Therefore, the various sounds are cognized by the ear consciousness and the mental consciousness, by these two consciousnesses.
What are the various smells?
It refers to good smells, bad smells, and smells that are experienced as neutral.

The first one is known by the nose consciousness, received by the nose consciousness, and known by the thinking consciousness. Therefore, all smells are cognized by the nose consciousness and thinking consciousness.
What are the tastes?
They are agreeable, disagreeable, and neutral tastes.
The first one is known by the tongue consciousness, received by the tongue consciousness, and known by the thinking consciousness.
Therefore, all tastes are cognized by the tongue consciousness and thinking consciousness.
What is part of the tangibles?
They are smoothness, roughness, lightness, heaviness, cold, hunger, and thirst, etc.
The first one is known by the body consciousness, received by the body consciousness, and known by the thinking consciousness.
Therefore, part of the tangibles is cognized by the body consciousness and thinking consciousness.
What is called the unmanifest form?
It is the form included in the factor realm, which is cognized by the thinking consciousness alone at all times.
What is eye consciousness?
Based on the eye faculty, each separately perceives forms.
What is ear-consciousness?
Based on the ear faculty, each separately perceives sounds.
What is nose-consciousness?
Based on the nose faculty, each separately perceives smells.
What is tongue-consciousness?
Based on the tongue faculty, each separately perceives tastes.
What is body-consciousness?
Based on the body faculty, each separately perceives tactile objects.
What is mind-consciousness?
Based on the mind faculty, each separately perceives mental objects.
What is feeling?
It refers to the nature of sensation.
It is further of three kinds: painful, pleasant, and neither painful nor pleasant.
What is conceptualization?
It refers to the nature of comprehensive knowledge.
It is further of three kinds:
small, large, and immeasurable.
What is volition?
It refers to the mental activity of the mind, the function of the intention.
It is further of three kinds: wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.
What is contact?
It refers to the combination of the three [factors].
This is further divided into three types:
Experiencing pleasure, experiencing suffering, and experiencing neither pleasure nor suffering.
What is attention?
It is the transformation of the mind.
This is further divided into three types: that of learners, that of post-learners, and that of neither learners nor post-learners.
What is desire?
It is the nature of delight in action.
What is resolve?
It is the delight, nature of delight, and delight in action of the mind.
What is faith?
It is the utmost purity of the mind.
What is vigor?
It is the delight of the mind.
What is mindfulness?
It is the nature of the mind's clear recollection.
What is concentration?
It is the one-pointedness of the mind.
What is wisdom?
It is the discernment of dharmas.
What is investigation?
It is the nature of the mind's thorough investigation.
What is analysis?
It is the nature of the mind's subtle investigation.
What is heedlessness?
It is the non-cultivation of wholesome dharmas.
What is heedfulness?ğŸ”½It is the cultivation of wholesome dharmas.
The wholesome roots are the three wholesome roots:
The roots of non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.
As for the unwholesome roots, there are three unwholesome roots:
The unwholesome roots of greed, hatred, and delusion.
As for the indeterminate roots, there are four indeterminate roots, namely indeterminate craving, views, conceit, and ignorance.
What is indeterminate craving?
It refers to the five kinds of activities in the form and formless realms.
What is indeterminate views?
It refers to the views of self and extremes practiced in the desire realm, and the five views practiced in the form and formless realms.
What is indeterminate conceit?
It refers to the five kinds of activities practiced in the form and formless realms.
What is indeterminate ignorance?
It refers to the ignorance associated with the views of self and extremes practiced in the desire realm, and the five kinds of activities practiced in the form and formless realms.
As for the various bonds, there are nine kinds of bonds:
The fetters of greed, hatred, conceit, ignorance, views, adherence to particular views, doubt, anger, and stinginess.
What is the fetter of greed?
It refers to the greed of the three realms.
What is the fetter of hatred?
It has the nature of anger and resentment towards sentient beings.
What is the fetter of conceit?
It refers to the seven kinds of conceit, namely conceit, over-conceit, excessive conceit, self-conceit, superiority-conceit, lesser-conceit, and wrong-conceit.
What is conceit?
Considering oneself superior to an inferior,

or considering oneself equal to an equal, it is the cause for that. The holding of conceit, the chronic conceit, the elevation of the mind, the arrogance of the mind, the grasping of the mind, this is called conceit.
What is over-conceit?
Considering oneself superior to an equal, or considering oneself equal to a superior, it is the cause for that.
The special holding of conceit, the chronic holding of conceit, the elevation of the mind, the arrogance of the mind, the grasping of the mind, this is called over-conceit.
What is conceit?

It means to contemplate the five appropriated aggregates as either the self or what belongs to the self, and on that basis, to be arrogant, conceited, and haughty, with a mind that is lofty, arrogant, and grasping. This is called conceit.
What is overweening conceit?

It means to think that one has attained what one has not yet attained, or to think that one has realized what one has not yet realized or manifested, and on that basis, to be arrogant, conceited, and haughty, with a mind that is lofty, arrogant, and grasping. This is called overweening conceit.
What is low-grade conceit?

It means to think that one is slightly inferior to those who are much superior, and on that basis, to be arrogant, conceited, and haughty, with a mind that is lofty, arrogant, and grasping. This is called low-grade conceit.
What is false conceit?

It means that one who does not possess virtues thinks that one possesses virtues, and takes that as the cause for arrogance, conceit, and haughtiness, the mind being lofty, the mind being arrogant, and the mind being obstinate. This is called wrong pride.
These seven kinds of pride are called the fetter of pride.
What is the fetter of ignorance?
It means the lack of knowledge in the three realms. This is called the fetter of ignorance.
What is the fetter of views?
It means the three kinds of fetters are called the fetter of views.
What are the three?
First, the view of self;
Second, the view of grasping extremes;
Third, wrong views.
What is the view of self?

It means observing the five appropriated aggregates as either the self or what belongs to the self, taking that as the cause, acquiescing in and delighting in the wisdom and views, this is called the view of self.
What is the view of grasping extremes?

It means observing the five appropriated aggregates as either annihilation or permanence, taking that as the cause, acquiescing in and delighting in the wisdom and views, this is called the view of grasping extremes.
What is wrong views?
It means denying cause and effect and function, destroying existent things, taking that as the cause, and enduring, enjoying, contemplating with wisdom, and what is seen, this is called wrong view.
These three kinds of views are called the fetter of views.
What is the fetter of clinging to special views?
There are two kinds of clinging to special views, called the fetter of clinging to special views.
What are the two?
First, clinging to special views;
Second, clinging to special precepts and observances.
What is clinging to special views?

It means contemplating the five aggregates of clinging as the best, supreme, superior, and ultimate, taking that as the cause, enduring, enjoying, contemplating with wisdom, and what is seen, this is called clinging to special views.
What is clinging to special precepts and observances?

It means contemplating the five aggregates of clinging as pure, liberation, and emancipation, taking that as the cause, enduring, enjoying, contemplating with wisdom, and what is seen, this is called clinging to special precepts and observances.
These two kinds of clinging to special views are called the fetter of clinging to special views.
What is the fetter of doubt?
It is by nature doubt about the truths.
What is the knot of haste?
It is by nature mental confusion.
What is the knot of stinginess?
It is by nature mental grasping.
Therefore, it is called a knot.
As for bondage, the knots that have been explained are also called bonds.
However, there are three kinds of bonds, namely the bonds of craving, the bonds of hatred, and the bonds of delusion, and therefore they are called bonds.
As for the subtle and extensive, there are seven kinds of subtle and extensive.
What are the seven?
First, the subtlety and extensiveness of craving;
second, the subtlety and extensiveness of hatred;
third, the subtlety and extensiveness of desire;
fourth, the subtlety and extensiveness of pride;
fifth, the subtlety and extensiveness of ignorance;
sixth, the subtlety and extensiveness of views;
seventh, the subtlety and extensiveness of doubt.
What is the subtlety and extensiveness of craving?
The five kinds of subtlety and extensiveness are called the subtlety and extensiveness of craving.
What are the five?
Namely, the desire realm's attachment to be abandoned by seeing suffering, the desire realm's attachment to be abandoned by seeing the origin, cessation, path, and cultivation.
These five subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of desire.
What is the subtle and extensive of anger?
These five kinds of subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of anger.
What are the five?
Namely, the anger to be abandoned by seeing suffering, the anger to be abandoned by seeing the origin, cessation, path, and cultivation.
These five subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of anger.
What is the subtle and extensive of existence?
These ten subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of existence.
What are the ten?
Namely, the five bound to the form realm and the five bound to the formless realm.
What are called the subtle and extensive of attachment to existence bound to the form realm, the five?
Namely, the desire realm's attachment to be abandoned by seeing suffering, and the desire realm's attachment to be abandoned by seeing the origin, cessation, path, and cultivation.
The five fetters in the formless realm are also like this.
These ten subtle and extensive [afflictions] are called the subtle and extensive [afflictions] with desire.
What are the subtle and extensive [afflictions] of pride?
These fifteen kinds of subtle and extensive [afflictions] are called the subtle and extensive [afflictions] of pride.
What are the fifteen?
They are the five fetters in the desire realm, the five fetters in the form realm, and the five fetters in the formless realm.
What are the five kinds of subtle and extensive [afflictions] fettered by the desire realm?

They are the various kinds of pride that are eliminated by seeing suffering in the desire realm, the various kinds of pride that are eliminated by seeing the accumulation, cessation, and path in the desire realm, and the various kinds of pride that are eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
The five fetters in the desire realm, the five fetters in the form realm, and the five fetters in the formless realm are also like this.
These fifteen kinds of subtle and extensive [afflictions] are called the subtle and extensive [afflictions] of pride.
What are the subtle and extensive [afflictions] of ignorance?
These fifteen kinds of subtle and extensive [afflictions] are the subtle and extensive [afflictions] of ignorance.
What are the fifteen?
They are the five fetters in the desire realm, the five fetters in the form realm, and the five fetters in the formless realm.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
What are the five kinds of pride in the desire realm that are subtle and extensive?

Namely, the light of the view of suffering that is bound to the desire realm, the light of the view of the origin, cessation, and path that are bound to the desire realm, and the light of the cultivation that is bound to the desire realm.
Just as there are five in the desire realm, there are also five in the form realm and five in the formless realm.
These fifteen kinds of subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of ignorance.
What is subtle and extensive of views?
Namely, the thirty-six kinds of subtle and extensive are called the subtle and extensive of views.
What are the thirty-six?
Namely, twelve in the desire realm, twelve in the form realm, and twelve in the formless realm.
What are the twelve views that are bound to the desire realm and subtle and extensive?

Namely, the satkÄyadá¹›á¹£á¹­i and antagrÄhadá¹›á¹£á¹­i belonging to the desire realm, the wrong views and the mithyÄdá¹›á¹£á¹­i belonging to the desire realm that are eliminated by seeing suffering, and the wrong views and the mithyÄdá¹›á¹£á¹­i belonging to the desire realm that are eliminated by seeing cessation, and the wrong views and the mithyÄdá¹›á¹£á¹­i belonging to the desire realm that are eliminated by seeing the path, and the satkÄyadrá¹›á¹£á¹­i and antagrÄhadá¹›á¹£á¹­i belonging to the desire realm.
Just as there are twelve in the desire realm, there are also twelve in the form realm and twelve in the formless realm.
These thirty-six are called the extensive views.
What are the extensive doubts?
Twelve kinds of extensive are called the extensive doubts.
What are the twelve?
Namely, the four belonging to the desire realm, the four belonging to the form realm, and the four belonging to the formless realm.
What are the four extensive doubts belonging to the desire realm?
Namely, the doubt belonging to the desire realm that is eliminated by seeing suffering, and the doubts belonging to the desire realm that are eliminated by seeing the origin, cessation, and path.
The four bound to the form realm and the four bound to the formless realm are also like this.
These twelve kinds are called subtle and extensive doubts.
Therefore, they are called subtle and extensive.
As for the various secondary afflictions, those that are subtle and extensive are called the various secondary afflictions.
There are those that are secondary afflictions but not subtle and extensive, namely, the defiled formations other than the subtle and extensive mental factors.
As for the entanglements and abiding, there are eight kinds of entanglements and abiding.
What are the eight?
First, torpor;
second, sleep;
third, agitation;
fourth, regret;
fifth, envy;
sixth, stinginess;
seventh, shamelessness;
eighth, lack of conscience.
Therefore, it is called the entanglements and abiding.
As for knowing, there are ten kinds of knowledge.
What are the ten?
First, knowledge of dharmas;
second, inferential knowledge;
third, knowledge of others' minds;
Fourth, conventional knowledge;
Fifth, knowledge of suffering;
Sixth, knowledge of accumulation;
Seventh, knowledge of cessation;
Eighth, knowledge of the path;
Ninth, knowledge of extinction;
Tenth, knowledge of non-arising.
What is knowledge of dharmas?

It refers to the uncontaminated knowledge of all conditioned phenomena associated with the desire realm, the uncontaminated knowledge of the causes of conditioned phenomena associated with the desire realm, the uncontaminated knowledge of the cessation of conditioned phenomena associated with the desire realm, and the uncontaminated knowledge of the path that leads to the cessation of conditioned phenomena associated with the desire realm.
Furthermore, knowledge of dharmas is the uncontaminated knowledge in the stage of knowledge of dharmas. This is called knowledge of dharmas.
What is knowledge of other kinds?

It refers to the uncontaminated knowledge of all conditioned phenomena associated with the form and formless realms, the uncontaminated knowledge of the causes of conditioned phenomena associated with the form and formless realms, the uncontaminated knowledge of the cessation of conditioned phenomena associated with the form and formless realms, and the uncontaminated knowledge of the path that leads to the cessation of conditioned phenomena associated with the form and formless realms.
Furthermore, knowledge of other kinds is the uncontaminated knowledge in the stage of knowledge of other kinds. These are called knowledge of other kinds.
What is knowledge of others' minds?

Knowledge born from cultivation, the fruit of cultivation, based on what is cultivated, attained without regression, that wisdom which understands the mental activities of desire and form realms, and the mental factors of others' minds, which realizes and attains the present understanding of a portion of the uncontaminated dharmas, this is called knowledge of others' minds.
What is conventional knowledge?
It is contaminated knowledge, this is called conventional knowledge.
What is knowledge of suffering?

The uncontaminated knowledge born from the intention to understand the impermanent nature, the suffering nature, the empty nature, and the non-self nature of the five appropriated aggregates, this is called knowledge of suffering.
What is knowledge of the origin [of suffering]?

The uncontaminated knowledge that arises from the intention regarding the causes of contaminated dharmas as causes, origination, production, and conditions, this is called knowledge of the origin [of suffering].
What is knowledge of cessation?
The uncontaminated knowledge that arises from the intention regarding cessation as cessation, tranquility, excellence, and escape, this is called knowledge of cessation.
What is knowledge of the path [to cessation]?
That is, in the path, one gives rise to the intentionality of the path, suchness, practice, and emergence, and the wisdom that is undefiled. This is called the wisdom of the path.
What is the wisdom of extinction?

That is, one thoroughly understands suffering by oneself, cuts off the accumulation by oneself, realizes cessation by oneself, and cultivates the path by oneself. Taking this as the cause, one's knowledge, views, understanding, wisdom, and discernment are clearly understood, and one realizes it in the present. This is called the wisdom of extinction.
What is the wisdom of non-arising?
That is, because one thoroughly understands all suffering, there is no more wisdom to be known;ğŸ”½because one has cut off the accumulation, there is no more to be cut off;
because one has realized cessation, there is no more to be realized;
because one has cultivated the path, there is no more to be cultivated.
Taking this as the cause, one's knowledge, views, understanding, wisdom, and discernment are clearly understood, and one realizes it in the present. This is called the wisdom of non-arising.
As for views, although that wisdom is also the views, there are also views that are not the wisdom.

The eight forbearances that arise from the edge of direct realization, namely, the forbearance of knowing the Dharma of suffering, the forbearance of knowing the class of suffering, the forbearance of knowing the Dharma of accumulation, the forbearance of knowing the class of accumulation, the forbearance of knowing the Dharma of cessation, the forbearance of knowing the class of cessation, the forbearance of knowing the Dharma of the path, and the forbearance of knowing the class of the path, are called seeing.
That which is direct realization is also direct realization of knowing and seeing, therefore it is said to be direct realization.
What is attainment?
It is what is obtained by all dharmas.
What is the attainment of non-perception?
It is the cessation of mind and mental factors, characterized by the thought of liberation, for one who has abandoned craving for the sphere of universal purity but not for higher spheres.
What is the attainment of cessation?
It is the cessation of mind and mental factors, characterized by the thought of cessation, for one who has abandoned craving for the sphere of nothingness.
What is the existence of non-perception?
It is the cessation of mind and mental factors, characterized by the thought of non-perception, for one born among the gods of non-perception.
What is the life faculty?
It refers to the life span of the three realms.
What is homogeneity?
It refers to the similarity among sentient beings of the same class.
What is acquisition of place?
It refers to obtaining various objects.
What is acquisition of things?
It refers to obtaining the various aggregates.
What is acquisition of place?
It refers to obtaining the internal and external sense bases.
What is birth?
It refers to the accomplishment of the aggregates.
What is aging?
It refers to the maturation of the aggregates.
What is abiding?
It refers to the non-decay of conditioned phenomena.
What is impermanence?
It refers to the decay of conditioned phenomena.
What is a name-collection?
It is the same as the increased speech.
What is a phrase-collection?
It refers to the completeness of the text.
What is a syllable-collection?
Those very syllable-collections are called a syllable-collection.
What is space?
The cause of what is traversed is precisely space, which is unobstructed. Various kinds of form cannot completely cover it, and this is called space.
What is non-analytical cessation?
It refers to cessation that is not due to separation.
What is cessation through discrimination?
It is cessation and also separation.
Therefore, it is said that there are five kinds of dharmas:
First, form dharmas;
Second, mind dharmas;
Third, mental factors;
Fourth, dharmas not associated with the mind;
Fifth, unconditioned dharmas.
Treatise on the Five Dharmas in One Fascicle
